[SYNTAX]: Awkward word order in "I could only however that evening declare..."
[GRAMMAR]: Missing commas in complex sentences (e.g., "He had gone to pieces in consequence of news requiring—as on precipitate reflexion he judged—that he should catch...")
[LEXICON]: Ambiguous phrasing in "I flattered myself that I emerged on this occasion from the infancy of art"
[PUNCTUATION]: Overuse of em-dashes in dialogue ("‘Silly—about Vereker!’")

[STRUCTURE]: Sudden shift from Corvick's Paris departure to the narrator's visit to Bridges with minimal transition
[LOGIC]: Ambiguous reference to "the infancy of art" without clear contextual explanation
[CLARITY]: Unclear cause-effect relationship between the narrator's review and Vereker's reaction
[TRANSITION]: Abrupt jump from the narrator's internal monologue to Lady Jane's public reaction to the review

[SPELLING]: "He laughed main" (likely a typo for "laughed man")
[LEXICON]: "He’d take it upstairs with him and look at it on going to dress" (awkward phrasing)
[SYNTAX]: "He showed how much he was when before us all Lady Jane wanted to read something aloud" (cumbersome structure)

[LOGIC]: Sudden shift from Vereker's public dismissal of the article to his private apology lacks clear transitional context
[STRUCTURE]: The narrative abruptly ends with "I don’t know what he had at first meant to say..." without resolving the emotional arc
[CLARITY]: The phrase "He laughed main" disrupts narrative flow and creates confusion

[GRAMMAR]: "I’m as much in the dark as ever, though I’ve grown used in a sense to my obtuseness" (awkward phrasing).

[CLARITY]: "the very passion of his passion" (repetition reduces clarity).
[LOGIC]: "the critic just isn’t a plain man: if he were, pray, what would he be doing in his neighbour’s garden?" (abrupt metaphor without contextual setup).

[SYNTAX]: Complex sentence structures may slightly hinder readability.

[TRANSITION]: Some shifts between narrative and dialogue could be smoother.

[SYNTAX]: Overly convoluted sentence structure ("The elements were all in his mind, and in the secousse of a new and intense experience they just struck light").
[LEXICON]: Unusual/ambiguous word choice ("secousse" – likely a French loanword but contextually unclear without prior knowledge).
[PUNCTUATION]: Excessive use of em dashes creating fragmented flow ("That’s the way he knew it would come and the real reason—you didn’t in the least understand, but I suppose I may tell you now—why he went...").

[LOGIC]: Sudden shifts in narrative perspective (e.g., abrupt transition from Gwendolen’s description to narrator’s internal reaction).
[CLARITY]: Ambiguous references to prior context ("the figure in the carpet," "Vereker") that may confuse readers unfamiliar with the larger narrative.
[STRUCTURE]: Disjointed paragraph transitions (e.g., from Gwendolen’s dialogue to the narrator’s actions without clear linkage).

[GRAMMAR]: Incorrect tense in "have existed" (should be "had existed")

Ambiguous structure in "I could see meanwhile the torch she refused to pass on flame away in her chamber of memory—pour through her eyes..."

[SYNTAX]: "I was struck in the presence of these tidings with the fundamental detachment..." (awkward phrasing)

"The writer might go down to his grave: she was the person in the world to whom—as if she had been his favoured heir—his continued existence was least of a need." (complex, hard-to-follow sentence structure)
"I find myself quite as vague as a captive in a dungeon about the tinge that further elapsed before..." (confusing phrase "the tinge that further elapsed")

"I had foreseen, through my bars, this end of the business..." (unclear meaning of "through my bars")
[PUNCTUATION]: "I departed with the moral certainty that as the door closed behind me Deane would brand me for awfully superficial." (missing comma after "me")
